video_path: C:\Users\chris\Dropbox\Scripts\clip-video\brands\KCD-UK\videos\Prabhakaran Jayaraman Masani - Kubernetes for Beginners Breaking Down the Complexity.mp4
text: Hi everyone I'm Prabhakaran Jaraman Mahasani a Cloud Platform Architect at Vigimedia O2 Today I'm going to talk about kubernetes for beginners breaking down the So kubernetes is an open source platform which automates deployment scaling and management of containerized applications I would like to think kubernetes as a conductor of an orchestra who organizes containers musicians ensuring automation Even if one app fails kubernetes keeps the music playing So kubernetes cluster mainly contains a control plane and a worker node Control plane is like a brain a worker node is like a So control plane contains api server scheduler control manager and etcd api server is an entry point for the cluster scheduler assigns parts to controller manager maintains desired state and etcd stores the cluster configuration Worker nodes contains kubelet container runtime and kubeproxy Kubelet is like a node agent attached to each node container runtime helps to run your apps and kubeproxy manages networking You talk to the api server via kubectl a command line tool So core of kubernetes objects a pod is a smallest deployable unit usually one container A deployment is one which manages the life cycle of Services provide stable way to reach the pods via ip and dns Pods can restart move around but service stays stable So I would like to quickly show a demo with just three commands So the first command creates a deployment basically running your nginx application The second command exposes the application to the outside world In a cloud environment probably this would create a load balancer The third command kind of like shows you like your running state of your application Okay So you don't need a cloud to learn kubernetes Tools like minikube kind can be installed on your laptop and with a few commands you'll be able to run them locally So minikube start or create cluster can help you get started on your local machine I would encourage to experiment break fix and repeat So you will learn faster by doing Yep To recap cluster contains of control plane and worker nodes Pods runs apps Deployment manages the pods Services expose them You can practice with three commands locally You can use minikube kind Kubernetes has a vast documentation and you can learn the basics from kubernetes io Learn the lingo cluster node pod deployment service and there are many more You can join the community and share your journey Thank you

segments.text: Hi everyone I'm Prabhakaran Jaraman Mahasani a Cloud Platform Architect at Vigimedia O2
Today I'm going to talk about kubernetes for beginners breaking down the
So kubernetes is an open source platform which automates deployment scaling and management of containerized applications
I would like to think kubernetes as a conductor of an orchestra who organizes containers musicians ensuring automation
Even if one app fails kubernetes keeps the music playing
So kubernetes cluster mainly contains a control plane and a worker node
Control plane is like a brain a worker node is like a
So control plane contains api server scheduler control manager and etcd
api server is an entry point for the cluster scheduler assigns parts to
controller manager maintains desired state and etcd stores the cluster configuration
Worker nodes contains kubelet container runtime and kubeproxy
Kubelet is like a node agent attached to each node container runtime helps to run your apps and kubeproxy manages networking
You talk to the api server via kubectl a command line tool
So core of kubernetes objects a pod is a smallest deployable unit usually one container
A deployment is one which manages the life cycle of
Services provide stable way to reach the pods via ip and dns
Pods can restart move around but service stays stable
So I would like to quickly show a demo with just three commands
So the first command creates a deployment basically running your nginx application
The second command exposes the application to the outside world
In a cloud environment probably this would create a load balancer
The third command kind of like shows you like your running state of your application
Okay So you don't need a cloud to learn kubernetes
Tools like minikube kind can be installed on your laptop and with a few commands you'll be able to run them locally
So minikube start or create cluster can help you get started on your local machine
I would encourage to experiment break fix and repeat
So you will learn faster by doing
Yep To recap cluster contains of control plane and worker nodes
Pods runs apps Deployment manages the pods Services expose them
You can practice with three commands locally You can use minikube kind
Kubernetes has a vast documentation and you can learn the basics from kubernetes io
Learn the lingo cluster node pod deployment service and there are many more
You can join the community and share your journey Thank you
